person:biography.personal-details:content:
I am plant ecologist interested, broadly, in the study of ecological succession and plant community dynamics. During the earliest years of my research career I investigated the patterns, causes and mechanisms of vegetation recovery in tropical landslides, focusing on the role of environmental heterogeneity and human-induced disturbances in this process. I conducted the fieldwork of my PhD Thesis in Nicaragua, but I also worked in Puerto Rican landslides together with Lawrence Walker (UNLV, USA). I also collaborated in studies aiming to assess the main factors determining changes in species diversity across environmental gradients in high Andean communities and Mediterranean woodlands.
During the last few years I was involved in the project SpatioDiversity, headed by Thorsten Wiegand, which aimed to assess the major drivers of species coexistence in the moist tropical forest of Barro Colorado Island (Panama), from a spatially-explicit perspective. In particular, I was focused on the assessment of spatial signatures of broad community-assembly mechanisms such as niche-partitioning and habitat filtering, and processes such as density-dependent mortality, over long time frames.
Currently, I work in the Universidad de Magallanes (Chile), doing a teaching Post-doc and collaborating in the project "Sistema de Información en Biodiversidad para Aysén" (SIB-Aysén).
